body:
Issue 1 is a bug - thanks for pointing that out. 

Issue 2 is a known problem with rclone. Rclone doesn't really understand directories - see #100 

I may do a stop gap measure to get rclone to delete empty directories which would fix most of the problems.

rename.from: sync leaves empty folders behind on Google drive; --dry-run creates folders

body:
Thanks for the quick follow up!

Sorry I missed the earlier discussion on Issue 2, I'm a new user. A 'delete empty directories' step at the end of sync would be most welcome.
This also happens with swift so is likely a missing check in `operations.go`.

issue.title: b2: when using a subdir does a metadata read for every file when listing

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
So I tried `rclone` against a file tree with ~130.000 files in ~3.300 directories, totaling ~720GiB.

```
rclone copy --dump-headers --dump-filters --dump-bodies --log-file ~/rclone.log --dry-run --size-only --verbose --ignore-existing /home/pa/some/dir b2target:bucketname/targetdir/
```

Soon after, Backblaze notified me that my API call limit was about to be reached.
Turns out, `rclone` seems to request the remote filenames file by file instead of using the upper limit of 1000 files per API request. The log looks like an endless stream of this:

```
2016/02/15 13:14:58 HTTP REQUEST
2016/02/15 13:14:58 POST /b2api/v1/b2_list_file_names HTTP/1.1
Host: api001.backblaze.com
User-Agent: rclone/v1.27
...

{"bucketId":"5xxxc9baxxxxxxx95dxxxc12","startFileName":"some/path/to/one/file.txt","maxFileCount":1}
```

Note the `maxFileCount` is 1 but should be much larger.

I tried to locate the problem in the code but I can't find why `MaxFileCount` should be one here:
https://github.com/ncw/rclone/blob/master/b2/b2.go#L280

Any hints?

body:
The fix for creating directories on `--dry-run` will be in the next release - thanks for reporting it.

Nick
@ncw Unfortunately, this is reproduced on 1.44. When running `move` with `--dry-run`, empty folders are created in Google Drive.
@orange-buffalo can you please make a [new issue on github](https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/new) about this with a sequence of commands to reproduce please - thanks :-)

issue.title: move with --dry-run creates empty folders in Google Drive

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### Output of `rclone version`
```
$ rclone version
rclone v1.44
- os/arch: linux/amd64
- go version: go1.11.1
```
#### Describe the issue
##### Short story
`move` with `--dry-run` creates empty folders in Google Drive.
##### Details
On a local machine, there is a folder `/tmp/move-source` with a file and sub-folder with another file:
```
$ ls -R
.:
nested-folder  source-file.txt

./nested-folder:
nested-source-file.txt
```
On Google Drive (configured in `rclone` as `gdrive`), there is an empty folder `move-target`.

Execute `rclone --dry-run move /tmp/move-source gdrive:/move-target`
Output is as expected:
```
2018/10/21 09:32:58 NOTICE: source-file.txt: Not moving as --dry-run
2018/10/21 09:32:58 NOTICE: nested-folder/nested-source-file.txt: Not moving as --dry-run
```
But there is a folder `nested-folder` created in Google Drive:
```
You created an item in
    move-target
        nested-folder
```
#### Interesting facts
* Running `copy` with the same setup does not create empty folders.
* Running `sync` with the same setup does not create empty folders.
* There was a similar issue fixed in 1.28: #342

body: @ncw, sure thing, created #2676. Thanks for your fast response!
